contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox person | name = Irving Rapper | birth_date = {{Birth date|1898|01|16|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[London, England]], UK | death_date = {{Death date and age|1999|12|20|1898|1|16|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles, California]], USA | occupation = Dialogue director, director, assistant director, producer | years_active = 1929-78}} '''Irving Rapper''' (16 January 1898 – 20 December 1999) was a [[UK|British]] film director. His most successful body of work is 10 films he made while under contract with [[Warner Brothers]]. Rapper emigrated to the United States and became an actor and stage director on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] while studying at [[New York University]]. In 1936, he went to [[Hollywood]], where he was hired by [[Warner Bros.]] as an assistant director and dialogue coach. He proved invaluable in translating and mediating for non-native English-speaking directors. By the early 1940s, he had metamorphosed into one of the hottest directors on the Warner Bros. lot. He made his directing debut with the 1941 film ''[[Shining Victory]]'', in which his friend [[Bette Davis]] appeared as a show of support for him. He would go on to direct her in four more films, ''[[Now, Voyager]]'' (1942), ''[[The Corn Is Green (1945 film)|The Corn Is Green]]'' (1945), ''[[Deception (1946 film)|Deception]]'' (1946), and ''[[Another Man's Poison]]'' (1952). In later years, Rapper admitted that he found Davis very difficult to work with and that she would, "...hold the whole set hostage, stopping production for a day, because of her mood." Rapper's film ''[[One Foot in Heaven]]'' (1941) was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Film]]. Perhaps his best film in a studio other than Warner Bros. was ''[[The Brave One (1956 film)|The Brave One]]'' (1956), which earned the then-blacklisted writer [[Dalton Trumbo]] an [[Academy Award]] for his original screenplay. Additional credits include ''[[The Glass Menagerie (1950 film)|The Glass Menagerie]]'' (1950), ''[[Marjorie Morningstar (film)|Marjorie Morningstar]]'' (1958), and ''[[The Miracle (1959 film)|The Miracle]]'', a 1959 [[remake]] of the 1912 full-colour film ''[[The Miracle (1912 film)|The Miracle]]''. Biopics directed by Rapper include ''[[The Adventures of Mark Twain]]'' (1944), ''Pontius Pilate'' (1962) and his last film, the 1978 flop ''[[Born Again (film)|Born Again]]'', about convicted [[Watergate scandal|Watergate]] conspirator and former [[Richard Nixon]] aide [[Charles Colson]]. Rapper died at the age of 101 on 20 December 1999 at the Motion Picture and Television Fund home in [[Woodland Hills, Los Angeles]], where he had been a resident since 1995. ==See also== * ''[[Pontius Pilate (1962 film)|Pontius Pilate]]'' (1962 film) ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0710924}} *[http://www.theyshootpictures.com/rapperirving.htm Biodata] * {{Find a Grave|10298973|Irving Rapper}} {{Irving Rapper}} {{Authority control|VIAF=14963214}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Rapper, Irving | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American film director | DATE OF BIRTH = 16 January 1898 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[London, England]] | DATE OF DEATH = 20 December 1999 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Los Angeles, California]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rapper, Irving}} [[Category:1898 births]] [[Category:1999 deaths]] [[Category:American centenarians]] [[Category:American film directors]] [[Category:American Jews]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:People from London]] [[Category:Disease-related deaths in California]]
